@@ -0,0 +1,9 @@
+---
+title: Introduction to the Build a String Formatter
+block: workshop-string-formatter
+superBlock: full-stack-developer
+---
+
+## Introduction to the Build a String Formatter
+
+This page is for the Build a String Formatter

@@ -0,0 +1,42 @@
+---
+id: 68e4276483b0c71658aab1ca
+title: Step 1
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-1
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+In this workshop, you will practice working with various string methods used for formatting strings.
+
+Start by creating a variable called `userInput` and assign it the following value: `"   Hello World!   "`.
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should have a `userInput` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.exists(userInput);
+```
+
+Your `userInput` variable should be a string.
+
+```js
+assert.isString(userInput);
+```
+
+You should assign `"   Hello World!   "` to your `userInput` variable. Make sure there are two spaces before the `H` and two spaces after the `!`.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(userInput, "   Hello World!   ");
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+--fcc-editable-region--
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+```

@@ -0,0 +1,52 @@
+---
+id: 68e4276483b0c71658aab1cc
+title: Step 4
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-4
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+Your `userInput` value has some extra spaces at both ends of the string. To create a new string with that whitespace removed, you can use the `trim()` method.  
+
+Here is an example:
+
+```js
+const sentence = "  Learning about the trim method.  ";
+sentence.trim(); // "Learning about the trim method."
+```
+
+Create a variable named `cleanedInput` and assign it the result of using the `trim()` method on the `userInput` variable.
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should have a `cleanedInput` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.exists(cleanedInput);
+```
+
+Your `cleanedInput` variable should be a string.
+
+```js
+assert.isString(cleanedInput);
+```
+
+You should assign `userInput.trim()` to your `cleanedInput` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(cleanedInput, userInput.trim());
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+const userInput = "   Hello World!   ";
+console.log("Original input:");
+console.log(userInput);
+--fcc-editable-region--
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+```

@@ -0,0 +1,50 @@
+---
+id: 68e4276483b0c71658aab1cd
+title: Step 5
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-5
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+Now it is time to see the result.
+
+Start by adding a `console.log()` with the string `"Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:"`.
+
+Then below that `console.log()`, add another `console.log()` with the `cleanedInput` variable. 
+
+# --before-each--
+
+```js
+const spy = __helpers.spyOn(console, 'log');
+const getLogs = () => spy.calls.map(call => call?.[0]);
+```
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should log the string `"Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:"` to the console.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(getLogs()[2], "Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:");
+```
+
+You should log the `cleanedInput` variable to the console.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(getLogs()[3], cleanedInput);
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+const userInput = "   Hello World!   ";
+console.log("Original input:");
+console.log(userInput);
+
+const cleanedInput = userInput.trim();
+--fcc-editable-region--
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+```

@@ -0,0 +1,58 @@
+---
+id: 68e4276483b0c71658aab1ce
+title: Step 6
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-6
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+There will be times where you will want to only trim whitespace at the beginning of the string. That is where the `trimStart()` method comes in handy.
+
+Here is an example:
+
+```js
+const sentence = "  I love learning.  ";
+sentence.trimStart(); // "I love learning.  "
+```
+
+Remember that strings are immutable. This method will create a new string with the result. Not modify the original one.
+
+Create a variable `trimmedStart` and assign it the result of using the `trimStart()` method on the `userInput` variable.
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should have a `trimmedStart` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.exists(trimmedStart);
+```
+
+Your `trimmedStart` variable should be a string.
+
+```js
+assert.isString(trimmedStart);
+```
+
+You should assign `userInput.trimStart()` to your `trimmedStart` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(trimmedStart, userInput.trimStart());
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+const userInput = "   Hello World!   ";
+console.log("Original input:");
+console.log(userInput);
+
+const cleanedInput = userInput.trim();
+console.log("Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:");
+console.log(cleanedInput);
+--fcc-editable-region--
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+```

@@ -0,0 +1,67 @@
+---
+id: 68e4276483b0c71658aab1d0
+title: Step 10
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-10
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+There will be times where you will need to create a new string with a different casing. 
+
+To create a new string with all of the letters converted to uppercase, you can use the `toUpperCase()` method.
+
+Here is an example:
+
+```js
+const sentence = "I love to code!";
+sentence.toUpperCase(); // "I LOVE TO CODE!"
+```
+
+Create a variable called `upperCaseInput` and assign it the result of using the `toUpperCase()` method on the `cleanedInput` variable.
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should have a `upperCaseInput` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.exists(upperCaseInput);
+```
+
+Your `upperCaseInput` variable should be a string.
+
+```js
+assert.isString(upperCaseInput);
+```
+
+You should assign `cleanedInput.toUpperCase()` to your `upperCaseInput` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(upperCaseInput, cleanedInput.toUpperCase());
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+const userInput = "   Hello World!   ";
+console.log("Original input:");
+console.log(userInput);
+
+const cleanedInput = userInput.trim();
+console.log("Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:");
+console.log(cleanedInput);
+
+const trimmedStart = userInput.trimStart();
+console.log("After using the trimStart() method — leading spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedStart);
+
+const trimmedEnd = userInput.trimEnd();
+console.log("After using the trimEnd() method — trailing spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedEnd);
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+```

@@ -0,0 +1,86 @@
+---
+id: 68e4276483b0c71658aab1d1
+title: Step 12
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-12
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+If you need to create a new string where all of the letters are in lowercase, you can use the `toLowerCase()` method.  
+
+Start by creating a variable called `lowerCaseInput` and assign it the result of using the `toLowerCase()` method on the `cleanedInput` variable. 
+
+Then log the string `"Result of using the toLowerCase() method:"`.
+
+Finally, add another `console.log()` for the `lowerCaseInput` variable.
+
+# --before-each--
+
+```js
+const spy = __helpers.spyOn(console, 'log');
+const getLogs = () => spy.calls.map(call => call?.[0]);
+```
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should have a `lowerCaseInput` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.exists(lowerCaseInput);
+```
+
+Your `lowerCaseInput` variable should be a string.
+
+```js
+assert.isString(lowerCaseInput);
+```
+
+You should assign `cleanedInput.toLowerCase()` to your `lowerCaseInput` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(lowerCaseInput, cleanedInput.toLowerCase());
+```
+
+You should log the string `"Result of using the toLowerCase() method:"` to the console.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(getLogs()[10], "Result of using the toLowerCase() method:");
+```
+
+You should log the `lowerCaseInput` variable to the console.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(getLogs()[11], lowerCaseInput);
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+const userInput = "   Hello World!   ";
+console.log("Original input:");
+console.log(userInput);
+
+const cleanedInput = userInput.trim();
+console.log("Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:");
+console.log(cleanedInput);
+
+const trimmedStart = userInput.trimStart();
+console.log("After using the trimStart() method — leading spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedStart);
+
+const trimmedEnd = userInput.trimEnd();
+console.log("After using the trimEnd() method — trailing spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedEnd);
+
+
+const upperCaseInput = cleanedInput.toUpperCase();
+console.log("Result of using the toUpperCase() method:");
+console.log(upperCaseInput);
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+```

@@ -0,0 +1,107 @@
+---
+id: 68e4276483b0c71658aab1d2
+title: Step 13
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-13
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+There will be times where you will need to use multiple methods to create a new string. Over the next few steps, you will use some of the methods you have learned so far to create a new string that uses the camelCase naming convention.
+
+Start by creating a variable called `lowercaseWord` and assign it the string `"camelcase"`. 
+
+Below that `lowercaseWord` variable, create another variable called `camelCasedVersion` and assign it an empty string for now.
+
+Below that `camelCasedVersion` variable, add a `console.log()` with the string `"Camel cased version:"` followed by another `console.log()` for the `camelCasedVersion` variable.
+
+# --before-each--
+
+```js
+const spy = __helpers.spyOn(console, 'log');
+const getLogs = () => spy.calls.map(call => call?.[0]);
+```
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should have a variable called `lowercaseWord`.
+
+```js
+assert.exists(lowercaseWord);
+```
+
+Your `lowercaseWord` should be a string.
+
+```js
+assert.isString(lowercaseWord);
+```
+
+You should assign the string `"camelcase"` to your `lowercaseWord` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(lowercaseWord, "camelcase");
+```
+
+You should have a `camelCasedVersion` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.exists(camelCasedVersion);
+```
+
+Your `camelCasedVersion` variable should be a string.
+
+```js
+assert.isString(camelCasedVersion);
+```
+
+You should assign an empty string to your `camelCasedVersion` variable.
+
+```js
+assert.isEmpty(camelCasedVersion);
+```
+
+You should log the string `"Camel cased version:"` to the console.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(getLogs()[12], "Camel cased version:");
+```
+
+You should log the `camelCasedVersion` variable to the console.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(getLogs()[13], camelCasedVersion);
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+const userInput = "   Hello World!   ";
+console.log("Original input:");
+console.log(userInput);
+
+const cleanedInput = userInput.trim();
+console.log("Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:");
+console.log(cleanedInput);
+
+const trimmedStart = userInput.trimStart();
+console.log("After using the trimStart() method — leading spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedStart);
+
+const trimmedEnd = userInput.trimEnd();
+console.log("After using the trimEnd() method — trailing spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedEnd);
+
+const upperCaseInput = cleanedInput.toUpperCase();
+console.log("Result of using the toUpperCase() method:");
+console.log(upperCaseInput);
+
+const lowerCaseInput = cleanedInput.toLowerCase();
+console.log("Result of using the toLowerCase() method:");
+console.log(lowerCaseInput);
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+
+--fcc-editable-region--
+```

@@ -0,0 +1,76 @@
+---
+id: 68f405c8c9df44132c8fe1bb
+title: Step 15
+challengeType: 1
+dashedName: step-15
+---
+
+# --description--
+
+As you recall from earlier lessons, the camelCase naming convention starts with a lowercase letter for the first word, and each subsequent word begins with an uppercase letter followed by lowercase letters.
+
+Here are some reminder examples: 
+
+```md
+freeCodeCamp
+camelCase
+learningIsFun
+```
+
+The second word in the `lowercaseWord` variable is `"case"`. To access the `c` in that word, you can use `lowercaseWord[5]`. 
+
+Use the `+` operator to concatenate `lowercaseWord.slice(0, 5)` with the result of using the correct method for converting strings to uppercase on `lowercaseWord[5]`.
+
+Now you should see `camelC` in the console.
+
+# --hints--
+
+You should concatenate `lowercaseWord.slice(0, 5)` with `lowercaseWord[5].toUpperCase()`.
+
+```js
+assert.equal(camelCasedVersion, lowercaseWord.slice(0, 5) + lowercaseWord[5].toUpperCase());
+```
+
+You should NOT assign the literal string `"camelC"` to the `camelCasedVersion`. Please re read through the instructions for the correct approach.
+
+```js
+assert.notMatch(code, /camelCasedVersion\s*=(["'])camelC(["'])/);
+```
+
+# --seed--
+
+## --seed-contents--
+
+```js
+const userInput = "   Hello World!   ";
+console.log("Original input:");
+console.log(userInput);
+
+const cleanedInput = userInput.trim();
+console.log("Result of trimming whitespace from both ends:");
+console.log(cleanedInput);
+
+const trimmedStart = userInput.trimStart();
+console.log("After using the trimStart() method — leading spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedStart);
+
+const trimmedEnd = userInput.trimEnd();
+console.log("After using the trimEnd() method — trailing spaces removed:");
+console.log(trimmedEnd);
+
+const upperCaseInput = cleanedInput.toUpperCase();
+console.log("Result of using the toUpperCase() method:");
+console.log(upperCaseInput);
+
+const lowerCaseInput = cleanedInput.toLowerCase();
+console.log("Result of using the toLowerCase() method:");
+console.log(lowerCaseInput);
+
+const lowercaseWord = "camelcase";
+--fcc-editable-region--
+const camelCasedVersion = lowercaseWord.slice(0, 5)
+--fcc-editable-region--
+console.log("Camel cased version:");
+console.log(camelCasedVersion);
+```
